dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, so, did you see that article about Kazakhstan's PISA results and, uh, reading literacy? It's pretty eye-opening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, so, did you see that article about Kazakhstan's P I S A results and, uh, reading literacy? It's pretty eye-opening.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I did! Ninth last out of 77 countries, right? [Host_A: Mmm-hmm] That'sâ€¦ pretty stark, to be honest.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I did! Ninth last out of seventy seven countries, right? That's... pretty stark, to be honest.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When it comes to reading literacy, Kazakhstan is the 9th last out of 77 countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it is. I mean, our 15-year-old students' reading scores, they kinda dropped from 390 to 387, which isn't statistically significant. But, like, compared to the OECD average of 487?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it is. I mean, our fifteen-year-old students' reading scores, they kinda dropped from three hundred ninety to three hundred eighty seven, which isn't statistically significant. But, like, compared to the O E C D average of four hundred eighty seven?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Compared to 2009 our 15-year-old students reading results lowered from 390 to 387 scores which is considered non statistically significant. But compared to average OECD scores of 487, it equals to more than two-school-year difference.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's like a two-school-year difference, isn't it? Just on reading. It's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's like a two-school-year difference, isn't it? Just on reading. It's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But compared to average OECD scores of 487, it equals to more than two-school-year difference.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And the author, Aliya Bizhanova, even mentioned she's shocked sometimes when, uh, Almaty teachers or principals write with errors. It kinda makes you wonder.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And the author, Aliya Bizhanova, even mentioned she's shocked sometimes when, uh, Almaty teachers or principals write with errors. It kinda makes you wonder.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When I read their survey results, I am shocked if a teacher or principal of Almaty city school writes with errors what can we say about overall reading literacy of young people or general public?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It does, but you know, she also made a really good point that it's not *just* about the education system. There's a direct link with fewer books at home, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does, but you know, she also made a really good point that it's not just about the education system. There's a direct link with fewer books at home, too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, the issue is not only about education. OECD results show, that there is direct link between decreasing number of books at home and students literacy level.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. She said reading culture isn't born in school; it's, like, when parents read to their one-year-olds. But what do we see now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. She said reading culture isn't born in school; it's, like, when parents read to their one-year-olds. But what do we see now?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The culture of reading is not being born in school, it becomes a habit when a mother or father read to their child when he or she is one-year-old or younger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Phones. TVs. Video games. All the time. [Host_A: Right?] You know, not classical literature or even just fairy tales.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Phones. TVs. Video games. All the time. You know, not classical literature or even just fairy tales.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I see a lot of parents with mobile phones, there are TVs, cartoons and video games on a lot at home. I am not talking about social media posts or short blogs, I mean reading classical literature, at least fiction or childrens fairy tales.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. She gave that example from Great Britain, where they give books to nine-month-old babies at clinic visits. That's, uh, proactive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. She gave that example from Great Britain, where they give books to nine-month-old babies at clinic visits. That's, uh, proactive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, to encourage family reading time, 9-month old baby and his/her parents in Great Britain are provided books during outpatients clinic visit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's brilliant! And then she talked about libraries. She works from a district library and said she only sees, like, one or two people all day.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's brilliant! And then she talked about libraries. She works from a district library and said she only sees, like, one or two people all day.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I often work from home sitting in the district library (there are children and adult libraries combined) and am sometimes there full day. Based on my experience, do you know how many people visit a library to read or take/return books? You will be shocked, but it is usually one or two people maximum.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] I know! It's so sad. Dark rooms, dusty books, like, nothing's changed since the 80s, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! It's so sad. Dark rooms, dusty books, like, nothing's changed since the eighty seconds, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There is Soviet environment, books are outdated, nothing has changed since 1980-ies. ... There are dark rooms with dusty stacks of books.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Whereas in developed countries, they're like these bright, modern community centers. E-libraries, events for adults and kids...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Whereas in developed countries, they're like these bright, modern community centers. E-libraries, events for adults and kids...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Libraries in developed countries are considered centers of districts called Community Centers, where interesting events take place for adults and kids - there is entertaining environment where books and journals are interesting to read, there are great e-library resources, public events, play time, there is light and open space.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Mmm-hmm. And her conclusion, I think, was the most important part. Instead of huge amounts on Expo or new curbs, we should be investing in transforming *our* libraries.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mmm-hmm. And her conclusion, I think, was the most important part. Instead of huge amounts on Expo or new curbs, we should be investing in transforming our libraries.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It then makes more sense to invest in local libraries and in their transformation, rather than to spend huge amounts of money on Expo exhibition or new curbs that are regularly replaced in Almaty city.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, make them places people actually *want* to go. For us, for our kids.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, make them places people actually want to go. For us, for our kids.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Seriously. They're just surviving right now. Imagine if they thrived.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously. They're just surviving right now. Imagine if they thrived.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I can surely understand that there are some financial issues and our libraries are surviving.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, it's about building that reading culture back, isn't it? From home right through to our public spaces.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, it's about building that reading culture back, isn't it? From home right through to our public spaces.
